reasoning:
The critique targets the paper’s “no serious, coordinated efforts to promote the overall best outcomes de dicto” baseline (Sec. 3.1) and, secondarily, the framing in Sec. 2.2 that a liberal-abundance future is a salient default to stress-test for hidden moral flaws. That baseline matters to how the paper operationalises ‘easygoing vs fussy’ (probability of mostly-great futures under default drift), but it is not the core driver of the main conclusion, which is largely grounded in (i) value fragility/multiplicative-factor intuitions and (ii) the taxonomy of value functions (bounded/unbounded, aggregation) implying fussiness. Even if the critique is right, it more naturally implies ‘eutopia is even harder’ (because power-seeking optimisation pushes toward lock-in) rather than undermining ‘no easy eutopia,’ so centrality is moderate.

On strength: the institutional claim (default dynamics favor concentrated interests optimizing for control/rents) is plausible and gestures at a concrete alternative “key risk” (capture → stable low-flourishing lock-in). But it is mostly asserted rather than argued: it doesn’t show that Forethought’s baseline is the wrong counterfactual for the concept it wants (absence of de dicto optimisation), nor does it establish that philosophical/moral-error failure modes are less important than governance capture—indeed governance capture could be one additional multiplicative factor or a mechanism that increases the probability of the listed moral catastrophes. Also, Forethought’s broader framework explicitly treats power concentration/lock-in as a core risk, so the critique risks being partly “priced in,” reducing its marginal refutational force.

Relevance is high because it engages Forethought’s active governance/lock-in concerns (power concentration as a co-equal risk, feasibility of lock-in, institutional path dependence) and suggests a potentially important interaction: the ‘default’ distribution over surviving futures may be shaped by adversarial optimisation rather than neutral drift, which could change how flourishing work should be framed or prioritised. Overall, it’s a useful reframing prompt but not a strong refutation of the essay’s main argument.
title: Existing power structures undermine the neutral default assumption
